conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum.
The graph shows acceleration as a function of time. The object starts from rest, so initial velocity v0 = 0.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, acceleration is constant and positive (a = 2 m/s²).
From t = 1 s to t = 3 s, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
From t = 3 s to t = 4 s, acceleration becomes negative (-2 m/s²).
Velocity can be calculated using the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
Velocity at any time t is given by v(t) = ∫ a(t) dt + v0. Since v0 = 0, v(t) = ∫ a(t) dt.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, v(1) = ∫0^1 2 dt = 2 m/s.
From t = 3 s to t = 4 s, v(4) = ∫3^4 (-2) dt = -2 m/s.
The velocity at t = 1 s is 2 m/s, at t = 3 s is 0 m/s, and at t = 4 s is -2 m/s.
The maximum velocity occurs at t = 1 s.
